prompt_inputs.content: Microplastic contamination in coastal marine sediments represents a critical environmental challenge with complex ecological implications. Advanced spectroscopic techniques like Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy enable precise characterization of microplastic polymer compositions, revealing predominant polymers such as polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) in sedimentary profiles. Quantitative analysis indicates microplastic concentrations ranging from 15-42 particles per kilogram of sediment, with potential bioaccumulation risks in marine food webs.
